byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Alexandra Odynova from St. Petersburg, Ivan Nechepurenko from Moscow, Kareem Fahim from Cairo, Nicola Clark from Paris, Jad Mouawad from New York, and Peter Baker from Washington.
byline.original: By ANDREW E. KRAMER and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

abstract: Russian investigators and aviation experts are still trying to determine why Russian charter plane broke up in midair over Sinai Peninsula, leaving open possibility that plane either experienced mechanical failure or was subject of terrorist attack; mourners visit impromptu shrine erected at St Petersburg's Pulkovo Airport for 224 passengers on flight, and flags across Russia are flown at half-staff.
lead_paragraph: A day of mourning was held Sunday for 224 who died in the Egyptian Sinai crash, while the transportation minister said flight recorders had been found.

headline.main: Amid Vigils and Debris, Officials Seek Cause of Sinai Peninsula Crash
headline.print_headline: Amid Vigils and Debris, Officials Seeking Cause of Crash in Egypt

snippet: A day of mourning was held Sunday for 224 who died in the Egyptian Sinai crash, while the transportation minister said flight recorders had been found.
